posts.name: Sam Knight
posts.cooked: Does anyone have a good reference for setting up a workflow for tube cutting using a jig?  We have a Shapeoko 3XXL and are interested in setting up a jig to help up our capabilities for tube work.  Assuming we have a jig in place, how do you go about zeroing your start on the tube center to ensure that when you flip your tube both sides will be cut symmetrically?

posts.name: Mike Marandola
posts.cooked:
For edgefinding we simply just get the cutter close to the side of the tube, switch it to single step mode (how to do this varies by machine), then just step over a thou at a time while spinning the tool. You’ll be able to see when it touches we move up out of the way in Z, zero, and move over half the diameter of the cutter.

As for keeping it centered when you flip it, take an actual measurement of the tube. It’s sometimes a couple thousandths oversized. If that’s the case we make our offset be the centerline of the tubing and move over half the measured width of the tubing (1.003” or something)

We used only MAXtube this year, which was very close to nominal, so we just zeroed on the corner and went to town.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: We have an Omio, with WCP’s Tube jig.  We basically eyeballed the zero spot and did a test cut on a piece of scrap tubing.  Measured the results with calipers, adjusted, and cut again - repeat until happy.  Once we had a good zero, we saved that fixture location so we can easily get to the corner of the tube.  We’ve found that to be accurate enough so far, without needing to worry too much about how accurate the width of the tube is.

posts.name: Steven Smith
posts.cooked: In addition to Mike’s tip (how we do it as well), I’ll usually try to cut a few non-critical features first (like this year, half depth pockets in our arm for lightening), and then caliper between that feature and the edge on both sides. If I detect an offset, I’ll adjust it before I cut the more critical features (holes/locating features).

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
knightscape:

how do you go about zeroing your start on the tube center to ensure that when you flip your tube both sides will be cut symmetrically?

To find centerline, I use this method in a mill.  It’ll work for routers too.

-edge find an axis.  Set it as zero, do not offset for the edge finder radius. -edge find the same axis on the other side of the part. -note the value.  If you’re edge finding  a 1 inch wide tube, the value you should see should be around 1.200" -Divide that number by 2.  The exact centerline is that answer. -move the spindle to that answer and zero the axis. -you are now working from the centerline of the tube and when you turn it over to cut the other side, your axis will still be zero’d on the centerline.

Here are some crude drawings that might help better explain the text above.

edge find center 1.pdf (64.8 KB) edge find center 2.pdf (61.7 KB)

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
What tools are people using for zeroing routers?

Traditional wobble edge-finders work great at low mill spindle speeds (~1k rpm), but I’m not willing to put one in our router to find out “the fun way” if it’ll hold up at 8k rpm (our porter-cable’s lowest setting).

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

I’m not willing to put one in our router to find out “the fun way” if it’ll hold up at 8k rpm

Huh.  I guess I forgot about that when I said the method I described above would work on a router.  FWIW, I have seen an edgefinder experience 8k+ rpm on a machining center…  It wasn’t happy.

I guess one could put a known size “thing” (dowel pin, shank of something…) into the spindle then use a feeler gage with the method I described.

posts.name: Steven Smith
posts.cooked: I just use the single flute router bit. I measure it first (caliper/micrometer) to verify size, and then rotate it by hand as I step 0.001" into the part, when the tip drags (and I usually see a little burr as it bites into the material), I’m there.

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
Steven_Smith:

I measure it first (caliper/micrometer) to verify size

I realize this doesn’t matter too much on FRC parts, but doesn’t the side opposite the cutting edge have relief for chip clearance?

i.e. The center of the cutter to the cutting edge is the radius of the nominal cutting diamter. The center of the cutter to the side opposite the cutting edge is less than the cutting edge side, above.  That shorter distance is the clearance area for chips. So, measuring with calipers/micrometer will give a diameter less than the nominal size marked on the cutter?
